review.title: Subjective Knowledge Acquisition and Enrichment Powered By Crowdsourcing
review.abstract: Knowledge bases (KBs) have attracted increasing attention due to its great success in various areas, such as Web and mobile search.Existing KBs are restricted to objective factual knowledge, such as city population or fruit shape, whereas,subjective knowledge, such as big city, which is commonly mentioned in Web and mobile queries, has been neglected. Subjective knowledge differs from objective knowledge in that it has no documented or observed ground truth. Instead, the truth relies on people's dominant opinion. Thus, we can use the crowdsourcing technique to get opinion from the crowd. In our work, we propose a system, called crowdsourced subjective knowledge acquisition (CoSKA),for subjective knowledge acquisition powered by crowdsourcing and existing KBs. The acquired knowledge can be used to enrich existing KBs in the subjective dimension which bridges the gap between existing objective knowledge and subjective queries.The main challenge of CoSKA is the conflict between large scale knowledge facts and limited crowdsourcing resource. To address this challenge, in this work, we define knowledge inference rules and then select the seed knowledge judiciously for crowdsourcing to maximize the inference power under the resource constraint. Our experimental results on real knowledge base and crowdsourcing platform verify the effectiveness of CoSKA system.

Then, we formulate the ST pair selection problem as the Maximum Knowledge Inference problem, which is NP-hard, and propose a diversity-conscious, greedy algorithm for ST pair selection.

sections.heading: 4. CROWDSOURCED ST PAIR APPLYING
sections.text: For a particular ST pair, the task of subjective knowledge acquisition is to determine the prevailing opinion on whether the subjective property can be applied to the instances of the type referred to as the Crowdsourcing ST pair. However, it is too costly to ask the crowd for each instance, as one type in a KB could contain hundreds of thousands of instances. Therefore, we formulate the Crowdsourcing ST pair, which is considered a binary classification problem, taking advantage of the knowledge in the KBs. In each case, we decide whether the ST pair can be applied by the classification result. However, we do not have any designated data to train the classifier. Therefore, we select a number of seed instances and ask the crowd-sourcing samples to collect the corresponding subjective knowledge facts. We take the crowd-sourcing samples as training data and train the classifier on the basis of the attributes extracted from the KB, as we would have these relationships in a series of KB / KB relationships.

sections.heading: 7. RELATED WORK
sections.text: In this section, we discuss the work related to subjective knowledge acquisition, knowledge base enrichment, and crowdsourcing. Subjective knowledge acquisition is closely related to works that associate characteristics with entities. Some work has been done for common sense knowledge acquisition [18] [15] [24]. WebChild [23] is a method for automatically building a large healthy knowledge base, it contains triples that associate nouns with adjectives about fine-grained relationships. Entitytagger [5], presented by Chakrabarti et al., automatically associate descriptive phrases, referred to as etags (entity tags), to each entity. Instead of subjective characteristics, these works focus on the less controversial and objective characteristics, which have nothing to do with obtaining dominant opinion. The most similar work is SURVEYOR, which holds the prevailing opinion on web properties, whether a subjective property is applied to a property.

sections.heading: 8. CONCLUSION
sections.text: Our CoSKA system consists of three stages: ST pair selection, Crowdsourcing-ST pair application, and Knowledge Conclusion. To resolve the conflict between large-scale knowledge facts and the limited crowdsourcing resource, we define subjective knowledge conclusions between ST pairs and conduct knowledge conclusions to derive more knowledge facts. We formulate the ST pair selection problem as a maximum knowledge inference problem that is NP-hard, and propose a diversity-conscious, greedy forward algorithm for ST pair selection. Crowdsourcing-ST pair application problem is formulated as a classification task to further improve the scalability of the system. Experimental results on a real-world knowledge basis and crowdsourcing platform that compares an accurate crowdsourcing system at high cost, could substantiate SKA facts with an extensive crowdsourcing system.

Subjective knowledge differs from objective knowledge in that it has no documented or observed ground truth. Instead, the truth relies on people’s dominant opinion. Thus, we can use the crowdsourcing technique to get opinion from the crowd. In our work, we propose a system, called crowdsourced subjective knowledge acquisition (CoSKA), for subjective knowledge acquisition powered by crowdsourcing and existing KBs. The acquired knowledge can be used to enrich existing KBs in the subjective dimension which bridges the gap between existing objective knowledge and subjective queries.
